user_message:
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters. This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn. Provide your answer with these fields. - is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false), - scenario: a specific violation scenario. Here is the code of fill_v1_v2_form: ```c static enum MHD_Result fill_v1_v2_form (const void *cls, const char *mime, struct Session *session, struct MHD_Connection *connection) { enum MHD_Result ret; char *reply; struct MHD_Response *response; size_t slen; (void) cls; /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */ slen = strlen (SECOND_PAGE) + strlen (session->value_1) + strlen (session->value_2); reply = malloc (slen + 1); if (NULL == reply) return MHD_NO; snprintf (reply, slen + 1, SECOND_PAGE, session->value_1, session->value_2); /* return static form */ response = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback (slen, (void *) reply, &free); if (NULL == response) { free (reply); return MHD_NO; } add_session_cookie (session, response); if (MHD_YES != MHD_add_response_header (response, MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_ENCODING, mime)) { fprintf (stderr, "Failed to set content encoding header!\n"); } ret = MHD_queue_response (connection, MHD_HTTP_OK, response); MHD_destroy_response (response); return ret; } ``` Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function fill_v1_v2_form: #define SECOND_PAGE "Tell me moreprevious
%s, what is your job?
" Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze: ```c MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback (slen, (void *) reply, &free); ``` Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
scenario: No. The call to MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback itself does not use any <string.h> function and it is passed a pointer (reply) and length (slen) that are within the allocated object bounds. slen was computed as strlen(SECOND_PAGE) + strlen(session->value_1) + strlen(session->value_2) and the code allocated malloc(slen + 1), so reading slen bytes from reply remains within the allocated buffer. (In fact, because SECOND_PAGE contains two "%s" tokens, strlen(SECOND_PAGE) counts those two characters, so slen actually overestimates the formatted output length, making the usage conservative.) Note: a violation could occur if session->value_1 or session->value_2 were not NUL-terminated or if the format string contained unexpected format specifiers, but as shown there is no Rule 21.17 violation here.
